questions.question_text: Express each number as a product of its prime factors: (i) 140 (ii) 156 (iii) 3825 (iv) 5005 (v) 7429
Find the LCM and HCF of the following pairs of integers and verify that LCM × HCF = product of the two numbers: (i) 26 and 91 (ii) 510 and 92 (iii) 336 and 54
hints: Find prime factors of both numbers
HCF = product of common prime factors with lowest powers
LCM = product of all prime factors with highest powers

questions.question_text: Find the LCM and HCF of the following integers by applying the prime factorisation method: (i) 12, 15 and 21 (ii) 17, 23 and 29 (iii) 8, 9 and 25
hints: Find prime factors of all numbers
HCF = product of common prime factors across all numbers
LCM = product of all prime factors with highest powers
Use formula: LCM × HCF = product of two numbers

questions.question_text: Check whether 6n can end with the digit 0 for any natural number n.
hints: A number ends with 0 if it has factors 2 and 5

questions.question_text: Explain why 7 × 11 × 13 + 13 and 7 × 6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1 + 5 are composite numbers.
hints: Show both factors are greater than 1

questions.question_text: There is a circular path around a sports field. Sonia takes 18 minutes to drive one round of the field, while Ravi takes 12 minutes for the same. Suppose they both start at the same point and at the same time, and go in the same direction. After how many minutes will they meet again at the starting point?
hints: They meet when both complete integer number of rounds
Time = LCM of their individual times
